subject: Re: [junit] JUnit works great in IDE, how do I run it from a shell?
msgSnippet: ... I am pretty sure you are right that Netbeans has its own Junit and ANT. From what I can tell, Netbeans doesn t do any documentation of how what they do is
messageBody:
James Abley wrote:
> On 23/03/06, Pat Farrell <pfarrell@...> wrote:
>> I've had great luck with NB 5.0 and junit on my project.
>> But the output goes to the 'statistics' window
>> and that can't be cut and pasted using normal X conventions.
>> (I'm running it on a Mandrivia 2006 box with JRE 5.0)
>>

>
> First off, have you got the prerequisites? I would imagine Netbeans
> bundles its own version of ANT and JUnit, which is why it works in the
> IDE.
>
> http://ant.apache.org/manual/OptionalTasks/junit.html
>

I am pretty sure you are right that Netbeans has its own Junit and ANT.
From what I can tell, Netbeans doesn't do any documentation of how what
they do is different.

a quick 'locate' doesn't find any junit.jar, but
does find four likely renamed or copied version

[pfarrell@m64 folklore]$ locate junit.jar
/home/pfarrell/.netbeans/5.0/modules/ext/nbjunit.jar
/home/pfarrell/.netbeans/5.0/modules/org-netbeans-modules-nbjunit.jar
/opt/netbeans-5.0/ide6/ant/lib/ant-junit.jar
/opt/netbeans-5.0/ide6/modules/org-netbeans-modules-junit.jar

the ant it installs is in the /opt/netbeans directory tree

[pfarrell@m64 bin]$ ll ant
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 34 Mar 11 22:20 ant ->
/opt/netbeans-5.0/ide6/ant/bin/ant

Of course the IDE doesn't set any environment variables
so there is no $ANT_HOME
defined

I assume that they call it ant-junit.jar to avoid having other
junit.jar files conflict.

--
Pat Farrell
http://www.pfarrell.com/
